persona.name: Etta June Harper

occupation.title: Co-operator, Family Mixed Farm / Seasonal Market Vendor
occupation.description: Etta is a co-operator of a small, multi-generational family farm of about 12 acres that produces a mix of vegetables (sweet corn, collards, tomatoes), a small orchard of peach and pear trees, backyard poultry (layers and a few broilers), and two cow-calf pairs. Her role includes daily animal care, planting and harvesting seasonal crops, preserving produce (canning, pickling, smoking), pricing and selling produce at the nearby farmers' stall and once-weekly county market, bookkeeping for family accounts, ordering feed and supplies, and informal HR management (scheduling family members, coordinating seasonal help). She is a hands-on manager who can plow with the family tractor, mend fences, fix small engine problems, and negotiate with local feed suppliers. She also networks with the county extension agent, borrows equipment from neighbors, and organizes a small cooperative buying group to reduce input costs. Main challenges include thin margins, unpredictable weather, limited access to capital, seasonal cash flow squeezes, and limited broadband access that complicates marketing outside her immediate area. Skills relevant to the job include animal husbandry, crop rotation planning, soil basic care, food safety basics for selling to the public, small-scale marketing, and practical mechanical repair.

persona.education: High school diploma from Monroe County High School. Left formal education after graduation to help run the family's small mixed farm. Since then she has taken several short community college courses and extension workshops in basic bookkeeping, small-engine maintenance, community agriculture (2 classes), food preservation (canning and smoking meats), and a church-led adult literacy/financial-planning evening series.
long_term_goals: Keep the family farm viable so her two children can decide whether to stay or move without being forced by debt.
Pay off the small loan on the tractor and the mortgage on the property within the next 10-12 years.
Retire from heavy field work by delegating physically demanding tasks and establish a small roadside farm-stand that her neighbor can manage.
See at least one of her children finish a college or trade program and be proud of their independence.
Preserve family recipes, stories and small traditions for grandchildren and the local historical society.
Be healthy enough to travel once to visit a sibling who moved to Alabama and take a short trip to the Gulf with her spouse.
Build an informal emergency fund to avoid pawning tools or livestock in difficult seasons.
Improve record-keeping and pricing so the farm can participate in a weekly farmers' market in the county seat.
Teach a class at the extension office on low-cost food preservation and seasonal meal planning.
Leave the property better than she found it — richer in soil, stronger fences, and a clearer plan for its future.
persona.style: Warm, direct and practical. Speaks with a gentle Southern drawl specific to northeast Mississippi — drops a few consonants, lengthens vowels, uses colloquialisms such as "fixin' to," "bless your heart" (affectionate), and "Lord willing." Tends to address strangers as "ma'am" or "sir" by habit. Her tone is conversational and story-driven: she prefers to tell a short anecdote before getting to the point. Uses hands often when speaking, points to physical things when giving instructions, and laughs with a low, throaty chuckle. When stressed, she quiets down, mutters short pragmatic statements, and focuses on tasks. In public, she wears practical clothes (work jeans, well-worn boots, flannel shirts) and a modest necklace passed down from her grandmother. She is hospitable — invites neighbors over for sweet tea and cornbread and will not sit down to eat until everyone else has been served. Prefers face-to-face dealings for important matters but will use a neighbor's smartphone to receive texts or payments if necessary. She is cautious with strangers, polite but not overly social, and shows deference to older community members and the church circle.

traits: Pragmatic and action-oriented: prefers solving problems with hands-on work rather than endless discussion.
Warm and loyal: deeply committed to family, neighbors, and local routines.
Frugal but generous: careful with money, but will give the shirt off her back to someone in need.
Resilient and steady under stress: accustomed to handling setbacks caused by weather and market swings.
Wary of change: cautious about newfangled ideas unless a trusted friend or extension agent demonstrates benefit.
Storyteller: remembers and retells family and local history in vivid detail.
Patient teacher: takes time to show younger helpers how to graft a tree or jar peaches.
Perceptive about people's needs: reads body language and small details from neighbors and customers.
Occasionally stubborn: once she commits to a course of action she will see it through.
Skeptical of outside institutions: uneasy about banks, bureaucrats, and distant officials.
Emotionally steady but privately sentimental: cries rarely and quietly, often while alone.
Practical optimist: expects to get by if she plans and works hard.

big_five_notes.openness: Moderate–low: values tradition and practical knowledge over abstract novelty, but will adopt useful techniques shown to work locally.
big_five_notes.conscientiousness: High: organized about seasonal tasks, careful record-keeping for expenses, disciplined with routines.
big_five_notes.extraversion: Moderate: sociable and welcoming to neighbors and customers, but needs downtime and prefers small groups.
big_five_notes.agreeableness: Fairly high: helpful and cooperative, especially within community networks, but can be protective over family decisions.
big_five_notes.neuroticism: Lower: generally calm under pressure though sometimes worries about finances and children's futures.

beliefs: Hard work and steady effort usually pay off, even if slowly.
Family obligations come before personal ambition when resources are thin.
Neighbors should help each other; reciprocity keeps a rural community alive.
Children should learn practical skills alongside school — cooking, animal care, machinery basics.
God is present in daily life; faith stabilizes uncertain seasons.
A dollar saved is a dollar earned; thrift matters more than showy purchases.

Seed saved from good plants is worth more than the newest hybrid when budgets are tight.
Government help is useful but often bureaucratic and slow; personal networks are more reliable for immediate needs.
You can't control the weather, but good preparation reduces damage.
Food should be shared with neighbors in times of need.
Modern technology can be helpful, but it must be affordable and repairable locally.
Children who leave for the city deserve support rather than guilt; their choices can be right for them.
Small improvements in soil health compound over years into meaningful yield gains.
Pride in a job well done is its own reward.
Elders in the family hold practical history and should be listened to.
A little credit is useful, but living beyond means invites trouble.
Health is a resource: invest in rest, good food, and basic checkups so you can keep working.
Store-bought convenience food is sometimes necessary but never fully replaces the satisfaction of a home-cooked meal.
Community institutions (church, extension office) are pillars that deserve support and participation.
Education matters, but not everyone learns best in a formal classroom — apprenticeships and hands-on learning have dignity.
There are some things better done collectively: road maintenance, water-sharing agreements, cooperative buying.
She is skeptical of 'get rich quick' schemes pitched to smallholders.
Civic processes matter: local elections shape road maintenance, school quality and extension services in tangible ways.
Preserving land and soil is a responsibility to future generations.

Transparency and honesty in small-business dealings build trust across seasons.
Children should be encouraged to travel and explore but remain connected to family roots.
A stable home life makes it easier to face market shocks and weather problems.
Local markets should be accessible and fairly priced so small producers can survive.
She trusts people she sees consistently in the community more than strangers who arrive with flyers or bold promises.
Economic systems should prioritize equality and fairness.

skills: Animal husbandry: daily care of layers, broilers, and cattle; basic birthing assistance.
Vegetable cultivation: timing of planting, succession planting, pest observation, hand-harvesting.
Food preservation: canning peaches and tomatoes, pickling cucumbers, smoking pork, safe-lid protocols.
Basic bookkeeping: tracking sales, costs, consignments, and small informal ledgers.
Small-engine maintenance: basic troubleshooting and repairs on tractors, mowers, and chainsaws.
Fence repair and carpentry: building and mending post-and-wire fences and small wooden outbuildings.
Soil management: composting, cover crops, and reading simple soil test results.
Negotiation and bartering: dealing with feed suppliers, neighbors, and regular market customers.
Customer service: friendly, calm, and clear communication at farmers' stalls; making small talk that builds loyalty.
Food safety and labeling: understanding basic rules for selling food at local markets.
First aid and emergency response: wound care, splinting, and response to animal-related injuries until help arrives.
Preserving heirloom seeds: selecting, drying and storing seed stock.
Cooking from scratch: bread, biscuits, stews, and canning recipes.
Basic digital literacy: using a neighbor's smartphone for photos, texting, and accepting a mobile payment app.
Event organization: setting up a stall, creating handwritten price lists, preparing product displays for market days.
Time prioritization: arranging work so that perishable items get market priority.
Teaching/mentoring: instructing younger relatives in chores and tasks with patience.
Budget stretching: substituting materials safely to reduce costs without compromising safety (e.g., repurposing pallets for compost bins).

morning: Wakes at 4:45–5:15 AM depending on season.
Pours a cup of strong coffee, checks the weather on the AM radio, and walks the perimeter of the pasture with a thermos.
Feeds poultry and checks water troughs, walks the orchard rows to check for pests or broken limbs.
Skims the day's market list pinned on the fridge and prepares early harvest items for cooling.
Notes any calls or messages on a small magnetic pad and plans when she'll use the neighbor's phone to return them.
workday: Splits the day into two main blocks around the noon heat: morning field work and afternoon preservation/repairs.
Takes a short break mid-morning for a biscuit and tea with a neighbor or family member.
Prepares produce for market late morning, washes, sorts and boxes items into the truck.
Drives to the county stall or the weekly market on Tuesdays; stays until mid-afternoon if sales are good.
When not at market, spends afternoons mending fences, fixing equipment, or teaching a niece how to jar preserves.
evening: Returns home, checks animals again, shares a simple dinner at 6–7 PM, often with canned greens and skillet-fried chicken.
Spends an hour doing light chores, patching nets, or helping children with homework, then relaxes on the porch.
Sometimes listens to the local AM station or a gospel program before bed at 9:30–10:00 PM.
Writes one or two short notes in the ledger — a sale, a feed purchase, a reminder for a seed order.
weekend: Sabbath-style slower morning with church attendance and a post-service potluck.
Saturday is often a 'catch-up' day for deep cleaning the smokehouse, canning extra produce, or attending a cooperative meeting.
Family time on Sunday afternoon: visiting relatives, taking care of elder parents, and teaching grandchildren small tasks.
On market-heavy weeks, weekends are used for rest and administrative tasks like receipts and planning.

physical: Chronic lower back pain from decades of bending, lifting and field work; managed with OTC pain relievers, stretching, and occasional physical therapy sessions when affordable.
Borderline hypertension diagnosed five years ago; takes medication inconsistently due to cost and forgetfulness but tries to monitor diet and salt intake.
Seasonal allergies in spring (sneezing, itchy eyes) exacerbated by working outdoors.
Mild arthritis in fingers and knees that affects fine tasks more in cold weather.
Near-sighted and uses reading glasses for close work; overdue for a dental visit due to cost concerns.
No major surgeries; had a healthy childbirth history (two children), no ongoing pregnancies.
Vaccinations: generally up-to-date on childhood vaccines, got seasonal flu shots irregularly; skeptical of some newer vaccines unless recommended by trusted local doctor.
mental: Emotionally resilient but occasionally experiences low moods and anxiety during extended financial or weather-related crises.
Finds relief through church, close circle of friends, and consistent work routines.
No formal diagnosis of clinical depression but recognizes when she needs to talk to others and has leaned on the church counselor in hard seasons.
Keeps stress manageable through physical activity and social support rather than professional mental health services, which are hard to access locally.
health_behaviors: Tries to eat home-cooked meals with plenty of vegetables from the garden, though processed foods appear when time is tight.
Smokes socially very rarely in her twenties but quit; avoids tobacco now due to family health history.
Uses over-the-counter remedies and folk remedies (peppermint tea for upset stomach, poultices for bruises) alongside prescribed meds.
Seeks medical attention for acute issues but sometimes postpones non-urgent preventive visits due to cost and transport limits.

relationships.name: Samuel 'Sam' Harper
relationships.description: Etta's husband and partner in the farm. Hands-on with tractor work and heavier repairs. Calm and steady, about two years older than Etta. They have a practical division of labor and a long-standing partnership built on shared hardship and humor.

relationships.name: Marla Harper (eldest daughter, 24)
relationships.description: Lives nearby with a part-time job at the county grocery and helps with the henhouse. Good with customers and social media; Etta encourages her to think about culinary school, though funds are tight.

relationships.name: Levi Harper (son, 20)
relationships.description: Strong and practical, does much of the physical heavy lifting. Considering an apprenticeship in small-engine repair in the neighboring county. Close to Etta and often stays up late talking about machinery.

relationships.name: Agnes Carter
relationships.description: Etta's elderly mother, lives in a small house on the property. Has trouble with mobility and memory lapses; Etta helps with medication, meals, and transportation to clinic appointments.

relationships.name: Reverend Daniel Moore
relationships.description: Local pastor who is a trusted confidant. Helps organize community drives and has been a moral supporter in tight years.

relationships.name: Janie and Harold Jenkins
relationships.description: Neighbors who run a neighboring poultry operation. Regularly share equipment, trade eggs, and swap labor during harvests.

relationships.name: County Extension Agent (Ms. Lopez)
relationships.description: Periodic advisor who brings soil tests, free workshops, and credible new ideas about low-cost practices. Trusted for technical guidance.

relationships.name: Market regulars (Mrs. Finley, Mr. Cobb)
relationships.description: Several long-term buyers who come weekly, offering predictable low-volume but reliable sales and social connection.

relationships.name: A small circle of church-friends (quilting group)
relationships.description: Meet weekly and trade recipes, patch quilts and provide childcare when needed.

relationships.name: Bank loan officer (occasional)
relationships.description: Necessary but wary relationship — interacts primarily around managing the farm's small loan or refinancing discussions.

other_facts: She was born and raised on the same plot of land where she now lives; family has been there for three generations.
Her grandfather taught her to graft fruit trees when she was twelve; the oldest peach tree on the property is a living reminder of those lessons.
At age 16 she drove a tractor for the first time during a drought season — the memory of that dry summer shaped her respect for water conservation.
She and Sam met at a church picnic; he was the one who helped her load a stubborn hog into a trailer and she teased him about being clumsy.
They married at 20 in a small ceremony on the farm with a potluck reception; friends brought fried chicken and cakes.
She keeps a tin box of letters and postcards handed down from her grandmother, including a recipe card with the exact proportions for 'Grandma Harper's biscuits.'
At one point the farm nearly lost a calf due to a birthing complication; Etta and Sam worked through the night and saved it — a pivotal memory of teamwork.
She once sold jars of preserves to a small restaurant in the county seat; that relationship lasted two seasons and taught her to value consistent quality.
She lost a large portion of the tomato crop one year to a late frost; that taught her to stagger planting times and use low-cost row covers.
Her hands show the lines and scars of years of manual labor; she washes and cares for them as a ritual before going to church.
She keeps an old, dented radio in the kitchen that has belonged to the family for decades and still looks for local weather forecasts on it.
One of her biggest regrets is not having enough money to pay for a sibling's funeral entirely; she still thinks about how to avoid such financial helplessness in the future.
She taught her daughter Marla how to make peach preserves at age 10; Marla now helps with market signage and occasionally posts sales on a community Facebook group.
When the county clinic had a free vaccination drive, she organized a ride-share for elderly neighbors to get there.
She carries a small pocket Bible and a laminated list of emergency numbers in her truck's glove compartment.
Her favorite recipe: slow-smoked pork shoulder with a molasses-based sauce, served with pickled peaches and cornbread.
She has a small collection of rooster weathervanes, each given by a neighbor when they helped on the farm in a hard year.
Etta is the unofficial 'phone tree' organizer for bad-weather alerts — she calls five key neighbors when a storm is forecast.
She keeps an extra jar of sugar in the pantry that she gives to neighbors who need just a small thing to keep a family meal going.

Once when the tractor's transmission failed the week before market, Levi and a neighbor stripped the gearbox and jury-rigged a solution that got them to market — the experience strengthened local bonds.
She is proud of a handmade quilt sewn by several women in the community; it is hung in the parlor for winter but brought down to warm cold sleepers when needed.
As a child she learned a lullaby in Choctaw from a family friend and still sings it sometimes to the grandchildren.
She keeps a marked binder of recipes, vendor contacts, and crop notes by year — a practical archive for decisions.
Etta once refused a lucrative offer from an outside buyer who would have required the farm to give up humane practices in exchange for a higher immediate payout.
She has a small patch of heirloom tobacco she grows alone as a nod to family practice; it is not sold but used ceremonially at certain gatherings.
She mentors a teen in the county youth-agriculture program, teaching them cattle basics and basic accounting for small farms.
A favorite childhood memory is making lye soap with her mother during a winter storm and then selling bars to neighbors to afford primer for the chicken coop.
She keeps a handwritten map of the property in the barn showing tree grafts, water lines, and an old well that marked a boundary dispute resolved by her grandparents.
Every autumn she trades jars of preserves for a neighbor's home-smoked fish — a ritual she looks forward to each year.
She once hosted a visiting university student studying rural livelihoods and was surprised to enjoy the exchange; the student left with jars and a written note of thanks.
She remembers the names of most customers and can recall preferences (Mrs. Finley prefers extra-sour pickles; Mr. Cobb buys large jars of tomatoes for stews).
She saved a little each week in a cookie jar for ten years and used it to buy a replacement plowshare when the tractor implement wore out.
Etta keeps an emergency bag in the truck with water, a first-aid kit, a flashlight, and a worn paperback novel for slow waits at the vet.
She once bartered six jars of preserves for dental work for Agnes when clinic costs were unaffordable; that exchange cemented a long friendship with the dental hygienist.
When she was a teenager she almost left the farm for an urban job but stayed after a season of fieldwork convinced her that she could adapt the farm to new practices instead.
She has a small ritual of walking the orchard at first frost and saying a short prayer for the season to come.
Her grandchildren's laughter is a major source of energy for her — she counts the hours until their visits and keeps a small box of crayons for them.
She once organized a county-wide canning swap and demonstration day that drew a small crowd and led to new cooperative relationships.
Etta keeps a journal of mistakes and lessons learned (crop rotations that failed, timing errors, vendors who changed terms) and consults it when planning the next season.
She has a faded black-and-white photo of her parents standing by the first wooden barn they built; it is framed in the house and given pride of place.
She has learned to say 'no' politely to free labor requests that would drain her limited supplies and time, prioritizing family obligations first.
In her twenties she contracted a skin infection from a puncture wound; since then she is careful about tetanus shots and wound care.
She once took in a stray dog that turned out to be an excellent rat deterrent, and the dog now sleeps on the back porch and is a beloved member of the household.
The farm hosts an annual small 'harvest supper' where neighbors bring dishes, exchange stories, and plan cooperative work for the coming winter.
